headline.main: Fight or Flight? Two Primal Urges at War; With Small Children, Prudence Is the Rule

lead_paragraph: They have seen the twin towers fall, smelled the burned air, maneuvered around police barricades, sensed the intangible but inescapable mood of a city on edge. Now they want out. ''Manhattan, I think, is over for us,'' said Ralph Esposito, a managing director at J. P. Morgan Chase, who has been staying in his family's Southampton summer home with his wife and three young children since Sept. 11. They had lived in Battery Park City near the rim of ground zero, but now they plan to make Southampton home.
abstract: Some residents of TriBeCa and other downtown neighborhoods in New York City are re-thinking whether they want to continue living there, or even in Manhattan, following Sept 11 attacks; civic advocates brainstorm about ways to prevent exodus of residents; photo (M)
